column11: Review Text
The Satmahal Prasada, the "seven-story tower" (but the top floor is only guessable) is a 12th century step pyramid. It is made of brick with square plan a side staircase.

The least understood structure at Polonnuwara, it is pyramid in shape, each level a square. Every side of every square had a deity in a niche. Resembling a ziggurat, it is unique in Sri Lanka. It may have been a less refined, early version of a stupa.
The structure give you a glimpse into the influences from other countries in the region on Sri Lanka...

In its time it would have been a very impressive structure with its 7 layers, (with figurines on the walls) now just 6 layers are showing (being ravaged by time), some figurines still visible. Not bad considering it is hundreds of years old.

This seven storied stepped temple is located in a corner of the Polonnaruwa ruins. It has entrances on all four sides and some liken it to a stupa where sacred relics related to a Buddha are housed. It does resemble temple structures found in Cambodia.
This unusual temple is located in the main Quadrangle.  It is a curiosity, feeling out of style with the adjacent temples
This is a 32 feet high stupa of unusual stepped pyramidal form. This structure built in the 12th century is said to resemble the type of stupa found in countries like Cambodia.
A very different style Stupa in the Polonnaruwn complex of Temples and buildings. This site is a must see for this and other amazing buildings on this site.

column8: One of the stops around Polonnaruwa
column11: This pyramid shaped ruin might have been an ancient form of stupa. You will see this on your way round the ruins.
For me this was one of the best ruins I saw, because most of it is still standing. The entries are closed.
This is a multistory building in ruines. Althoudh it is not restored, it is still nice and photogenetic

It is a Multi Storied brick structure, which is in ruins. Exposure to the elements have caused the outer layers to wither away and bricks are visible. Entry inside the structure is blocked. It is a relatively small structure which has not been restored. However, even in the present condition, it is quiet attractive and photogenic.
Our tour stops briefly to view, if my memory serves me correctly it was of Hindu origin. it had a presence about it.

This is a very fine ancient ruin and whilst it is not possible to enter inside it is certainly well worth stopping to marvel at this seven storied building and those incredible architects and builders who created it.

This is a stunnnimg ancient ruin by the sacred Quadrangle in Polonnaruwa. It was once a seven storied palace where the queen once lived but it is not possible to enter or climb it now. Instead what you can and should do is look at and marvel at the beautiful carvings on the stone and the sheer scale of what this building once must have been. I see one reviewer on this site calling it and ancient skyscraper! While that may be a little hyperbolic, I can see where he or she was coming from! Its right near the stone book and Hatadage and is well worth a stop.
Sathmahal Prasada means 7 Story palace .It was said the the queen is living there .As visitors we can't go inside this place ,But we can go to the very close .
Sathmahal Prasada is one of the ancient ruins at the Mahamewna Park in Polonnaruwa which will take you back centuries. A must see. Pls include this to your bucket list...
Great building structure in ancient kingdom. Seven stepped buliding. Located in polonnaruwa site closed with other important places.

This is a rather unusual stepped shaped stupa that sits in the North East corner of the "Quadrangle". It is unusual as it it not domed but is a  6 stories "step" stupa (originally it had 7 stories) very similar to those seen in Thailand and Cambodia. Stupa is in quite bad shape and most of the carvings are difficult to see. ( he best is above the entrance door (which is blocked off).

You need to take a secondary road to get here. It is rather small as a temple but cute. You cannot get inside. The nice part is that there are not so many people around. The vegetation sets it apart. I really liked it there. It felt fresh and relaxing
The remains of a stupa.The stupa is mostly damaged nothing much left. You can just see this walking past.

This is believed to be a stupa though it is built as a seven stepped structure. Not the usual style of stupas seen in Sri Lanka. This is also a part of the sacred quadrangle and you see it on your right as you enter the complex.
Included in your entrance ticket, not far from the Vatadage building. Is is more a large ruin that stands as most decoration has been destroited during the centuries.

This building is in a group of others that are more spectacular but is nevertheless interesting. The style of construction is quite different from the others here and has some Thai influences I think. Certainly worth a look and you should certainly come across it during any tour of the site
One of so many interesting ruins in Polonnaruwa, Sathmahal Prasada can easily be overlooked.  Quite nice, but you can also give it a pass if you're in a hurry.

I remember my guide telling me that this place was used to bury Monks. He said it is a sacred place. By the looks of it, it holds so much history and probably more that we don't know of, but nevertheless, it is part of this huge place where people used to live and worship.

When I rode up to this structure I was so excited I jumped quickly off my bike. A helpful man reminded me to take my water bottle to save it from thieving monkeys. It was so different from the rest of the ruins and it's history is unclear which I found to be very intriguing. To me this reminded me of something from Angkor which was exciting to see in the middle of a Sri Lankan lost city.

Rather unusual looking structure.,certainly not the most interesting in the Quadrangle. It is not clear what the function was either. With no shoes allowed on the religious sites, it can be uncomfortable to walk barefoot on the very hot sand and stones paths. It is best to wear socks.

No one seems to know who built this building or why. There seem to be no archaeological records for it at all. This is unusual in an area where there are fairly meticulous records for all the other structures. The style is reminiscent of a Babylonian Ziggurat. Perhaps there was an influence here?
A seven-stored pyramid monument in the area of Polonnaruwa Vatadage, very unusual for Sri Lanka and, for this reason, unique. Really worth the visit
This unusual six stepped pyramid shaped monument is in the Quadrangle section of Polonnaruwa and unike anything we've seen in Sri Lanka - so worth a quick photo on that basis alone.
Pyramid type structure which is intact not like the majority of other attractions. Unfortunately you are unable to get inside.
Seven (sath) storied ancient building. It is very different from the rest of the ruins in Polonnaruwa.

Sathmahal Prasada is quite a small seven-storied pyramid in the corner of Polonnaruwa Quadrangle. One can't get inside the building. Most people didn't even come up to Sathamal Prasada, or just came up and walked away, but I was really impressed by the place. It's nothing like the other buildings in Sri Lanka. It resembles the buildings in Siem Reap, or in some parts of Thailand. There's not much to see in or on it, but if one has a vivid imagination, or one likes Indiana Jones or Lara Croft movies, one would like the place.

This little building in the tooth relic temple complex just flabbergasted me as the architecture is very different from the other Lanka buildings.  It reminds me more of the temples of Ayutthaya, Bagan or Siam Reap.  Definitely worth a few moments of puzzlement and wonder...

This magnificent but small building consisting seven levels of narrowing rectangular design has given it the name Sath = 7, Mahal = Floors , prasadaya = palace or big building It could well be a place of worship either Buddhist or Hindu
This unique building is said to belong to an ancient form of architecture found in Thailand. It is pyramid shaped and consists of seven stories.
This is just another one of those remaining structures after war. The entire structure is blackened and one can see designs on the stone.

The remains of a royal palace belonging to a king of the Polonnaruwa era. Reportedly it had seven stories of which the ruins remain. The intricate plastering can be seen over the brick walls and the find at this location is the remains of a toilet and a septic tank which would have been in operation centuries ago.

built by king parakramabahu,this stepped pyramid shaped,seven storiedbuilding is thought to b an unusually shaped stupa.it is said that similar stupa can b seen in cambodia n siam.it is thoughtthis has been built for the cambodian soldiers who were working under the as a place of warship.this building has four entrance from four sides.there is a tunnel like processional pathin the basement round the monument.now only partly visiblebecause the entance to it has been closedup during subsequent period.this is made out of bricks and is over 30 feet hight

This is a 7 story building thought to be a stupa. Similar stupaâ€™s can be seen in Cambodia and Thailand. It is over 30 ft in height and is thought to have been built by Cambodian Soldiers working under the king.
